data.main_applicant_laboratory_name: Mountain Ecosystems Research Group, WSL Institute for Snow and Avalanche Research SLF
data.project_title: Seizing the treasure: making long-term environmental data available for eLTER and beyond
data.project_abstract: The European Long-term Ecosystem Research (eLTER) facility Stillberg was established in 1975 in a treeline ecosystem near Davos, Switzerland. In almost 50 years of research, we have collected a wealth of environmental and ecological data at this unique alpine site. These include monitoring data of a large-scale treeline afforestation experiment, meteorological data, time series of plant responses to free-air carbon dioxide enrichment, soil warming and nutrient addition, as well as plant-snow, plant-soil interactions, and drivers of tree seedling recruitment. In this project we aim at contributing these important ecological datasets from Stillberg as open research data (ORD). By curating the existing datasets before the upload to national and international ORD platforms (EnviDat and DEIMS-SDR) we will improve their visibility, quality, and availability. The provisioning of this long-term environmental data will foster transdisciplinary and global research syntheses and meta-analyses, improving our understanding of long-term ecosystem processes in mountain regions and supporting the development of adequate adaptation strategies.

project_title.reasoning: The title 'Seizing the treasure: making long-term environmental data available for eLTER and beyond' is consistently reported as the project title in both the Research Proposal table and repeatedly in proposal full title sections, with highest extraction confidence and explicit matches. A variant with the acronym '(StillbergDAT)' appears only in a support letter context. The 'Global Treeline Range Expansion Experiment G-TREE' is a section header, not the application/project title, based on context and absence elsewhere.

citation.matching_text:
Project title
> Seizing the treasure: making long-term environmental data available for eLTER and beyond

The European Long-term Ecosystem Research (eLTER) facility Stillberg was established in 1975 in a treeline ecosystem near Davos, Switzerland. In almost 50 years of research, we have collected a wealth of environmental and ecological data at this unique alpine site. These include monitoring data of a large-scale treeline afforestation experiment, meteorological data, time series of plant responses to free-air carbon dioxide enrichment, soil warming and nutrient addition, as well as plant-snow, plant-soil interactions, and drivers of tree seedling recruitment. In this project we aim at contributing these important ecological datasets from Stillberg as open research data (ORD). By curating the existing datasets before the upload to national and international ORD platforms (EnviDat and DEIMS-SDR) we will improve their visibility, quality, and availability. The provisioning of this long-term environmental data will foster transdisciplinary and global research syntheses and meta-analyses, improving our understanding of long-term ecosystem processes in mountain regions and supporting the development of adequate adaptation strategies.
data curation, DEIMS-SDR, eLTER research facility Stillberg, EnviDat, treeline ecology
data curation, DEIMS-SDR, eLTER research facility Stillberg, EnviDat, treeline ecology
data curation, DEIMS-SDR, eLTER research facility Stillberg, EnviDat, treeline ecology
data curation, DEIMS-SDR, eLTER research facility Stillberg, EnviDat, treeline ecology
data curation, DEIMS-SDR, eLTER research facility Stillberg, EnviDat, treeline ecology
The project will be completed within 6 months (June - November 2022).

config.system_prompt:
EXTRACTION STRATEGY:
  1. PRIMARY: Look for data in the specified location/table/section
  2. FALLBACK: If not found, search broader document context for semantically equivalent information
  3. FLEXIBILITY: Allow for format variations, OCR errors, and synonym usage

  LOCATION FLEXIBILITY:
  - Handle table format variations (column/row order, spacing, naming)
  - Consider synonyms and equivalent terms
  - Account for OCR/parsing errors that may affect document quality

  QUALITY STANDARDS:
  - Extract actual values found in the document
  - If uncertain, provide best interpretation with appropriate confidence
  - Only return null if the information category truly doesn't exist
  - Convert abbreviated amounts (k=1000) to full numbers where applicable
  

  METADATA EXTRACTION FOCUS:
  - Project identification: title, acronym, duration, start date
  - Applicant details: names, institutions, functions, addresses
  - Project categorization: Explore/Establish/Contribute classification
  - Keywords and abstract information from research proposal sections
